children.text: Bomba Festivals
This section covers the Encuentro de Tambores (f.2009) and Encuentros de Cantaoras.

In this audiovisual annotation set, I cover years 2022 through 2025. The 2022 Encuentro de Tambores was filmed by the Institute of Puerto Rican Culture and broadcast on local television. The Encuentro de Tambores features over three hundred bomba players and practitioners from various delegations. These include eight delegations divided by geography: Oeste, Norte, Este, Sur, Loíza, Carolinas, Cangrejos, and the diaspora.

What is particularly interesting about these festivals is that many of the songs performed are either premiered for the first time or composed specifically for the festival. The Enceuntros usually takes place in late March. The next Encuentro de Tambores will occur on a date yet to be announced.
The festival was founded by folklorist Norma Salazar in 2009, and is now co‑directed by Marien Torres of Taller Tambuyé.

Other festivals featured in this audiovisual annotation set include La Magia de los Tambores, an annual festival organized by the Familia Cepeda of La Escuela de Bomba y Plena Tata Cepeda. It was co‑founded by Bárbara and Margarita “Tata” Cepeda.

Another festival included here is La SanSe, which corresponds with the San Sebastián Street Festivals that occur in Puerto Rico, and in the diaspora (Orlando, Miami). This section of the site does not yet have annotations, but La SanSe is performed annually during late January.
Bomba in Commercial Music Videos
'Neo-Bomba' - Bomba Fusion Works
"Carita Linda" – Rauw Alejandro

"Carita Linda" is another bomba fusion work, released in 2025, produced with bomba practitioners from La Familia Cepeda such as Exan Cepeda (Ortiz), "Chino" Rafael Cepeda, and Roberto Cepeda. The video itself, in contrast to "Besito en la Frente," specifically highlights locality by displaying famous areas of Loíza such as the kiosks where people cook and consume alcapurria or traditional Afro-Puerto Rican food made with fried codfish. It also features the Loíza Aldea Museo de Arte de Puerto Rico, vejigantes, and community bombazos in Loíza.

The video also constitutes some confusion in displaying persons playing soccer instead of béisbol, which is considered more of Puerto Rico’s national sport, albeit soccer has been becoming more popular across pan-Latino communities at large. Additionally, the scenes involving horses—specifically paso fino, a breed imported to Puerto Rico from Spain—are notable. These horses are commonly seen roaming freely across the northeastern adjacent islands off the coast of Puerto Rico, such as Vieques and Culebra.

The elements that did not appear visibly nationalist were Rauw Alejandro’s outfits and the choreography chosen, whose footwork appears more akin to flamenco than bomba, though visually aligned with the scene of the paso fino horses Rauw rode in the film while performing. Scenes of typical quotidian or vernacular life are common in Puerto Rico, and bomba scenes are constantly interjected throughout.

This video is also significant in that it was the first to be termed "neo-bomba" by a periodical known as MSN, in an article titled Carita Linda: A Love Letter to Puerto Rico. Hector [apellido] expressed dislike for the term "neo-bomba," believing it was too confusing for the public, not clear enough, and detracted from the history of bomba as a tradition. He argued that it did not make sense because these commercial collaborations, although not totally out of the ordinary for bomba, had precedents. For example, Ismael Rivera and El Gran Combo had done salsa-bomba fusions in the [add decade]. It still did not make sense to hyphenate it.36
"Besito en la Frente" - Rauw Alejandro (2025)

In November 2025, Margarita Caridad "Cary" Martinez-Sanchez de la Familia Cepeda performed alongside Rauw Alejandro for "Besito en la frente" in its official extended video form. It is significant that over half of the video defines bomba as a genre and its cultural significance in a poetic manner. See narration below:

La bomba no es solo música, es la tierra hecha sonido, un latido que llegó de África y floreció en Puerto Rico. Un diálogo entre tambor, cuerpo y la voz colectiva, cada paso y cada golpe en el tambor nos recuerda que estamos conectados con el pasado y con el futuro. Una tradición nacida de la resistencia, que hoy sigue siendo una celebración de la libertad. Cada pueblo de Puerto Rico expresa la bomba a su manera. Los ritmos laten en la arena, un diálogo improvisado donde el cuerpo ordena y la música obedece. Los ritmos se mezclan con el carnaval y la energía del pueblo. Los vejigantes, mitad enigmáticos, tallados por artesanos y pintados con colores vibrantes, no son disfraces, son espíritus del Caribe. Despiertan la memoria ancestral de nuestro pueblo, son guardianes de la cultura, símbolos de resistencia que encarnan la eterna batalla contra lo oscuro. En cada máscara arde la fuerza de un pueblo que transforma el miedo en poder y la lucha en celebración. El baile de bomba es fuerza, tensión y libertad. La bomba es unión: une a pueblos y a generaciones, orgullo cultural Afro-Boricua. Cuando el ritmo llama, toda la comunidad responde.

This introduction to the song is especially significant because it reveals a larger difference in artistic strategies compared to Bad Bunny in terms of authenticity. As Hector has stated, "Rauw put in the work" to know bomba in a way closer to the community than Benito. He attended local bomba hubs such as Terraza de Bonanza, a chinchorro in San Juan known for hosting bailes de bomba, along with rumba, salsa, and plena. Rauw has also been taking classes directly from Jesús Cepeda and Mario Cepeda. His dedication to learning how to dance bomba is therefore more authentic and meaningful than the Bad Bunny collaboration, even though the Bad Bunny collaboration had a greater impact in regard to the international reception of bomba and in terms of total economic revenue generated for practitioners.
"Cultura" - Puya (2024)

"Cultura" is a bomba-heavy metal fusion piece that was released in 2024. For this project, Puya recruited members of El Tribu, and also included José Emmanueli of the distinguished Emmanueli brothers (Vitito, José, and Julio). The video also incorporated vejigantes, though in a morbid and unconventional manner that has been analyzed by heavy metal scholars [add citation here]. Despite the innovative blending of genres, the work did not achieve significant impact. While Puya has enjoyed popularity both in Puerto Rico and internationally, and is recognized for its experimentation with local Puerto Rican genres, narratives, and lyrics within the framework of metal and rock, the "Cultura" itself was not widely disseminated within the bomba community. In fact, I personally publicized its release through my academic social media account @ethnmusicologypr to raise awareness of its existence. Nevertheless, it represents another example of bomba circulating in new contexts and contributing to the discourse surrounding neo-bomba. Members of the bomba community responded positively to the effort, yet ultimately emphasized the cultural and economic influence of Rauw Alejandro and Bad Bunny, whose collaborations have had far greater resonance in shaping both the reception and the transnational visibility of bomba.
“De Carolina” - Rauw Alejandro (2022)

“De Carolina”37 was created by Reggaetonero Rauw Alejandro and DJ Playero, and it celebrates both urbanity and street culture in Carolina, Puerto Rico. Its significance lies in the fact that, in 2024, the Delegación del Carolina38 employed the introduction of the song at the Encuentro de Tambores before transitioning into a more traditional bomba style. This moment of paraphrase, or splicing, resembles practices in hip-hop and rap, where short melodic segments or lyrics are interjected into a new song to allude to a shared musical legacy. It is also important because it highlights how commercial collaborations are giving rise to a new subset of the genre, often referred to as neo-bomba, which fuses traditional bomba with commercial music. The bomba interpretation of “De Carolina” differs by shifting into a distinct chorus, yet it demonstrates how the younger generation is innovating within the genre. While this innovation risks losing sight of bomba’s “fundamentals,” it enriches the tradition by infusing youthful creativity. In doing so, it continues to celebrate places and acknowledge humble roots. This moment of musical overlap also shows that bomba practitioners not only collaborate with commercial music partners but also allow these shared spaces and collaborations to shape their own sense of musical experimentation and identity in profound new ways. Beyond this, this song also shows that Rauw Alejandro occupies a more 'authentic' place within the bomba community, than Bad Bunny. Rauw, unlike Bad Bunny, can be found dancing bomba in local spaces, such as [Terranza Bonanza and El Iman]. It's one thing to perform with bomberos, but its another to learn besides bomba elders.
Bomba in Film

The film Raíces (2001)—funded by Banco Popular in Puerto Rico and available on YouTube with partial support from the Institute of Puerto Rican Culture—is remarkable for the sheer range of musical genres it brings to the screen. It is especially significant for the visibility it gives to bomba. For its time, the film was revolutionary: it not only showcased traditional, autochthonous genres such as bomba and plena, but also incorporated hip-hop, reggae and rap.

The film’s overarching themes center on freedom, the legacy of slavery in the cane fields, and the historical roots of bomba. It explores the origins of plena, the cultural impact of the Familia Cepeda, and the intergenerational transmission of Afro–Puerto Rican traditions. One of its most compelling elements is its sonic preservation of the voices of bomba elders. The participation of the socially conscious rapper Welmo E. Joseph is especially notable. His sonic interjections weave between historical narration segments, adding layers of commentary with rhythm.

Raices’s structure alternates between contextual narration, interviews, and musical performances. It features a wide array of prominent Puerto Rican musicians, including members of the Familia Cepeda, Lucecita Benítez, and Pleneros de 21. The introduction and conclusion, with their ecological metaphors of roots and trees and the animated work of a Puerto Rican cartoonist, frame the film as a meditation on colonialism, cultural citizenship, and the politics of survival beyond necropolitical oppression.

Resistimos (2021) continues the legacy of showing bomba in different instances of resistance through film. It features the powerful voice of Marian Torres of Taller Tambuye and addresses both Hurricane María and the mass protests against government corruption. It situates bomba within contemporary struggles for dignity and justice. Filmed by independent filmmaker Diana Quiñones Rivera as part of her thesis at CUNY/Hunter College, the documentary blends political critique and music documentation.

The earliest of the three works, Zafra: Fusión Cepeda (1983) documents a live performance produced at the Centro de Bellas Artes. It includes many influential bomba practitioners from the 1980s and explores Puerto Rico’s tri-ethnic heritage through song. Some elements (such as the portrayal of Columbus and staged depictions of slavery) are intentionally provocative, prompting reflection on the island’s colonial history.

Together, these three films form a crucial cinematic archive of bomba over the past forty years. Because there is no centralized or formal archive dedicated to bomba, recorded performances, independent films, and platforms like YouTube play an essential role in preserving and understanding the bomba tradition . . . one that has long been marginalized by mainstream academic and cultural institutions.
In depth: Welmo’s Contributions to Raices

Welmo E. Romero Joseph is recognized in Puerto Rico for his contributions to the island’s hip‑hop movement and for his roles in films such as Raíces (2001), Talento de Barrio (2008), and El Viaje de Tortuga. He earned a Bachelor’s degree in Psychology from the Universidad de Puerto Rico, Río Piedras, and a Master’s degree in Communications, Media, and Cultural Studies from la Universidad del Sagrado Corazón. Since then, he has been actively involved in community work, particularly around issues of racial justice in Loíza.

His sonic interjections pack a punch. Short interludes that call attention to broader social issues that are addressed in the film. Welmo ensures the broader socio-political context in never neglected but does so with creative wordplay that highlights Puerto Rican’s adept tendency towards poetry as evidenced by our decima traditions or verbal dualism.
I have highlighted his parts within the documentary below and coded them according to their general content.
[1:12] Laboring to Remember Afro-Joy; Cultural Memory; Black Pride

Presuemiendo que mi gente se encuentre lista llega un cronista, protagonista de una historia que le rinde culto al ritmo el tambor y la cadencia dando esencia y vigencia a fuertes memorias reclamando un espacio al interior de una cultura que en ocasiones ha olvidado el espelendor de su negrura.

Assuming my people are ready, a chronicler arrives—protagonist of a story that pays homage to rhythm, to the drum and its cadence, giving essence and vitality to powerful memories, reclaiming a space within a culture that at times has forgotten the splendor of its Blackness.
[6:15] On Silences and Race

No pretendo ser el reemplazo de voces ausentes, ni decir que mi oratoria es la única referencia. Baile bomba, toques de plena—lo que digo vale la pena. Lo importante es la conexión del pasado con el presente.
I don’t pretend to replace absent voices, nor claim that my speech is the only reference. Dance bomba, play plena—what I say is worth hearing. What matters is the connection between past and present.
[10:12] Music and Race
Me levanto tomo aire sigo el ritmo me despejo en la sangre de una raza que se mira al espejo con las manos negras manos que se lanzan sobre el cuero. Canto, baile, ritmo. Canto, baile, ritmo.
I rise, I breathe, I follow the rhythm. I clear my mind in the blood of a race that looks into the mirror with Black hands—hands that strike the drum. Song, dance, rhythm. Song, dance, rhythm.
[16:51] Plena as Sonic Documentation

Es tiempo de un cambio de en boca y escena me presento en mis rimas el género de plena como crónica que narra lo que el barrio bien respira es periodismo melódico relatos fantásticos en realidad del la rabal su pobreza y su músico historias de sucesos al castigo, rústicos, sucesos condados de generación en generación brindando a la monotonía un nuevo curso de acción.

It’s time for a change. On the mic and on the stage, I present in my rhymes the genre of plena as a chronicle that tells what the neighborhood truly breathes. It is melodic journalism—fantastic stories rooted in the reality of the barrio, its poverty, its musicians. Tales of events and hardship, rustic stories passed down from generation to generation, giving monotony a new course of action.
[36:38] Freedom in the Context of Sound

La sensación del gusto, el roce de la tela y el sudor pasean juntos. Aumentan los latidos, temperatura en fiebre que le curó. No se calle, pues si callo no soy libre. Llamando y respuesta, resistencia y osadía, Aun con las cadenas, 24 horas al día. Mi voz viaja activa, sabiendo que quizás No vuelva a ver la luz del día. Tambor, dame el ser del sonido de tu alma. Tambor, cuida mi sueño con tu dulce melodía.

The sensation of taste, the brush of fabric, and sweat walk together. Heartbeats rise, fevered temperature healed. Do not be silent—for if I am silent, I am not free. Call and response, resistance and boldness, Even with chains, 24 hours a day. My voice travels, alive, Knowing that perhaps I may never see the light of day again. Drum, give me the being of your soul’s sound. Drum, guard my sleep with your sweet melody
[43:07] Gender Violence + “Cortaron Elena”

Viernes en la noche luna en cuarto menguante parada 22 de la plaza del mercado está dulce y elena se patean altanera viviendo su presente sin saber lo que espera la gente conversando la bbc tocando la lata de cerveza en el piso van quedando vecinos de la zona ya cerraron sus ventanas. Elena y su crónica de una muerte anunciada llegó Elena, preciosa Elena qué te parece Elena. Este hipo con la plena. Vives en tu vida que a tu modo mis maneras y por eso nena se cortaron sin problemas. Elenas mueren cada día por maltrato a un con nueve o sigo la ley 54.

Friday night, waning moon, stop 22 at the marketplace. There is Dulce and Elena, strutting proudly, living in the present without knowing what awaits. People talking, the BBC playing, a beer can rattling on the floor. Neighbors from the area have already closed their windows. Elena and her chronicle of a death foretold— Elena arrives, beautiful Elena, what do you think, Elena? This hiccup with the plena. You live your life in your own way, against my ways, and so, girl, things ended without problems. Elenas die every day from mistreatment, with a .9 or by following Law 54.
[C] “Soy Libre”, Freedom

Y soy libre, Libre como el río que en el mar desemboca. Libre las palabras que saltan de mi boca. Libre decido y alcanzo lo que quiero, Y aunque presto esté mi cuerpo. Es mi mente la que elevo. Libre es el aire que respiro Desde el momento en que nazco Hasta el último suspiro. Libre como el suelo de una isla que se expande, Libre es mi pueblo, y ante balas no se rinde. Libre, y soy libre. Libre, y soy libre

I am free— 
Free like the river that flows into the sea. 
Free like the words that leap from my mouth.

Free to choose and reach what I desire, 
And though my body may be bound, 
It is my mind that I lift.

Free is the air I breathe 
From the moment I am born 
Until my final sigh. 
Free like the soil of an island that expands, 
Free is my people, who do not surrender to bullets.

Free—and I am free. 
Free—and I am free.

As can be seen through these sections, Welmo’s role as rapper-narrator is vital to the success of the film. He calls attention to the silences, absences, and oppressions which sometimes slip from public memory. Whether that be through mentioning gender violence as a preface to the performance of the plena “Cortaron Elena,” or through sewing the throughline of freedom in juxtaposition with oppression through his words. Yet, it was for these reasons, and the inclusion of hip-hop and reggae that the original reception of the film originally faced some backlash. Since, in 2001, PR did not always read hip-hip as connecting closely with la isla due to Afro-diasporic musical marginalization.
Diegetic Sound in Resistimos (2021)

Another element worth highlighting in Resistimos (2021) is the film’s use of diegetic music and ambient sound. In particular, the interplay between nature‑based sounds—such as coquí calls and chickens—and the recurring presence of saxophone and piano as transitional devices between scenes.

The first instance appears at 2:21, accompanying images of the ocean. The choice of saxophone here may seem unexpected, yet it subtly gestures toward broader Afro‑diasporic sonic lineages that are not always immediately audible to the viewer. The playing style evokes jazz or avant‑garde improvisation, reinforcing these connections.

This motif returns during the sequence of Hurricane María news clips, where the saxophone is layered with distortion. The sax‑and‑piano pairing reappears over images of Mayagüez and Río Piedras, and again during the discussion of cultural labor and the creation of healing spaces, particularly in the segment featuring Marien Torres and the conversation about deaths following Hurricane María.

The film’s earliest diegetic sounds—chickens and a brief reference to le lo lai—set the tone for this sonic landscape. In the final scene, the appearance of baby chickens echoes Torres’s reflections on resilience and the loss of chickens after the hurricane, ultimately closing the film with an image that gestures toward renewal and hope.
